comments.commentBody: Everyone said Google was crazy when they released GMail, because Yahoo, Hotmail and other big players held the market. Google docs drove the market for collaboration and online computing even further. Today GMail is universally recognized as superior. Docs are still flaky but  better every year. And so it shall be with the Chromebooks. Sign me up, it can take its turn again my other laptops, and may the best platform win.

It's unfair to say that not a peep of protest has been heard. It's fair to say that the media have ignored and glossed over the protest because journalists don't understand the stock market any more than the average person does. While more and more of us have our lives tied to this system, few of us have a clue what it even does. Fiscal illiteracy not only lets these guys get away with grand theft, but it leaves us unable to defend ourselves.
Guess I need a lawyer to claim legally against one or  two of the fat cats. Does anyone touch that base?

I wonder why Cohan avoids naming Blankfein specifically, and I wonder if it has anything to do with the fact that their kids are in the same class.  Shouldn't this be disclosed?  I know it's private, but Cohan is one of the top financial writers, and Blankfein is head of Goldman Sachs.

Ever since the financial melt down, I have been asking myself why hasn't  the American populace 'stormed the Bastille".  And for the life of me I couldn't understand why.  Only recently did it occur to me why we have become "a nation of sheep".  The American baby boomers lived in the lap of the greatest luxury that any generation in the history of mankind has ever experienced.  They have completely bought into the idea that laissez faire capitalism is the only economic system that is viable.  And now that they are experiencing the down side of said system, they are completely confused as to what has happened but at the same time are incapable of considering the idea that maybe, just maybe, the myth that they have bought into is a fallacy.  An additional unfortunate outcome is that they, the boomers, have inculcated this idea of infallible capitalism into the psyche of the following or maybe even two following generations.  We have become akin to "deer in the headlights".  At the risk of badly paraphrasing professor Christopher Lasch (god willing that he were still alive):  Men created capitalism;  men can change it.  We better do so in a hurry.  To not do so will only make the on coming storm even worse.  I'm  a "boomer" and I am mortified as to what I have left my children.

"One of the most frustrating facts of the recently abated financial crisis is that those who might have been partly responsible for it have got off scot-free."

Parts shared added up to a culture of cheating, even betting on failure. The article that brought tears of anger to m'eyes was The End, by Michael Lewis (portfolio.com), published November 11, 2008.

Shannon,
These guys were not just skirting the law. They were blatantly and openly defying it, laughing all the way to the bank as they did it. They became part of the political process to protect their own interests. They chose who is in office Democrat or Republican.
Politicians can only blamed insofar as they are only doing the bidding of their employers and masters, not the voters.

Matt Taibbi has another fabulous report in the new Rolling Stone. http://www.rollingstone.com/politics/news/the-people-vs-goldman-sachs-20...

Taibbi describes Michigan Senator Carl Levin's 2-year investigation (available for download on Sen. Levin's website), which has done all the work for the Attorney General and the District Attorneys. Now it's on them to file the charges and put the perps behind bars. Sen Levin deserves a lot of credit for his tireless work. Here's one elected official who's not on the Wall Street payroll.

I've got a two-word solution: claw back.
I've even got a one-word solution: clawback.
QED

I would like to propose a "top 10 rule" of investing in stocks. DO NOT invest in any company whose CEO makes the top 10 list of most highly paid CEOs. A company like that is NOT looking out for shareholders. It is only looking out for its CEO. If enough people act on this, you will see a race to the bottom on CEO pay.

Experience has taught me that whenever there is an opportunity to take advantage of a situation to enrich oneself, many if not most folks will do so if they can get away with it. So it has to be the lawmakers and regulators who stand guard and smack down wrongdoers. The problem is that our lawmakers and regulators appear to be in the thrall of those wrongoers who happen also to be wealthy and powerful thanks to their predations. A vicious circle.

Sir, I didn't make it past the first sentence of your article where you term the fiscal debacle to have been. "...recently abated.." Maybe for pundits like yourself or beltway apologist that is true. Here in the real world of 20% real unemployment nothing has abated.
If you use such loose terminology your thinking on other matters is suspect and reading your thoughts would be a waste of time.

Save money overall by not buying a huge SUV that you use in everyday life to drive a few people a mile here or there because you really want to make sure you have that huge SUV for your family roadtrip. Rent one for the roadtrip if it is necessary, instead, and you'll save on gas the rest of the year.

I also recommend keeping track of traffic patterns. I just drove through the night 800 miles one way, and during the day, back home (another 800 miles). The night trip was much, much faster due to the lack of traffic and fewer stops for gas.

I totally agree that more people need to protest this and stop being so complacent. But I think we need protest the leaders of the banks and Wall St, not the banks and Wall St. general. I'm sure that a very small group of very powerful, very rich people run these institutions, perhaps in the spotlight and perhaps from behind those who are in the spotlight. These are the people who can make a change, and they can actually come out of the situation looking much better if they fight with the people to enact change. If they don't want to do what's right for the country, then they will get tarred and feathered like the Twain carpetbaggers that they really are. And everybody knows that the politicians won't do much, as has already been demonstrated. So how to protest? Hey it would be very interesting to see how our government would respond if people did take to the streets and didn't schedule an approved protest beforehand. But I'm sure that that won't happen, because we Americans are complacent and can just watch real protesters get shot on TV while guzzling a few beers and eating tasty potato chips. Because life ain't so bad when you can snack your life away in front of the TV.

via Google . . . "Terror" comes from the Latin verb terrere meaning "to frighten".
If Wall Street bankers didn't "frighten" the population I have no idea what will. Like other "terror" organizations these bankers need to be stripped of their assets, maybe put in Times Square stocks and committed to a life of cleaning toilets at public schools all across America wearing 'Greedy for Green' jackets, the same jackets French street sweepers use. Cheap and disposable, just like Wall Street attitudes.

As I said back when the too-big-to-fail bailouts began, and Obama then appointed Wall St insiders to oversee the process: the fix is in.  The fix is still in, Democrat in the White House not withstanding.  They are not going to tell you why they should not be held accountable for the same reason that they originally said they would not be held accountable.  Because they can, because they have the money, the power, and have continued to corrupt both parties to cover their bets.  The only way I can see anything getting better is for Jon Stewart or someone from Saturday Night Live to run for high office. Preferably very high.  Barring that, raise children and/or fresh basil and tomatoes-- life is short and ain't nothin' fundamental changin' anytime soon. But you knew that.

This is exactly what happens when ponzi scheme 2.0 meets legalized racketeering.

It seems to me the WSJ crowd would rather not frame this is as the "financial innovation" it was once dubbed.

Because the media industry in which your comment is posted refuses to keep such stories in the national dialogue, opting to keep the public constantly pumped full of frivilous content that makes them passive and ignorant of what really matters.

All of you folks just don't get it. This has been going on since the founding of this nation. The only difference is that people nowadays just automatically blame the government since Ronald Reagan told everyone that the government is the bad guy.

This is weird because we are the government. If we are the government, then we all are the bad guys, because this government is supposed to be by the people, for the people.

Even though we worship the rich in this culture and we hate the poor, we will never blame those that have more. We fear that. They may take it all away.

The very rich in this country have always tried everything they could to keep their money, keep making money, and keep anyone from having the opportunity to make money. The target of their fear is the poor whites, blacks and others that don’t fit in their little club.

We all have been complicit in this endeavor. Our hatred of others in the United States, the enemy of my enemy is my friend, is been the proverb that we live by that allows the rich to beat us all over the head, and we always seem to be satisfied with it.

The super wealthy will always win this argument.

I'm not a communist.

Kim n. must be smoking crack if she thinks it the Democrats who turn a blind eye to this type of abuse.  Last I checked it was the party-of-no who is trying to repeal the financial reforms put in place by Obama.   Get a clue.

Why don't we do more? Because it's human nature to move on. And if we didn't we'd still be trying war criminals from WWII, still digging into the false information that led to our invasion in Iraq, etc, etc.

For better or for worse, it's time to move on.

There are not many things I agree with Mr. Cohan about but, I certainly agree about the role of Wall Street and the Banks in the the Great Financial meltdown. I do think that Mr. Cohan has been kinder than I would have been if I were an opinionator. The trillions that disappeared will never be recovered and have been replaced with, in my opinion, a Dollar which is worth a minimum of 10% less, more probably close to 20% in just the past 4 years.

What raised my ire was their as well as Wall Streeters who move in and out of Government representing that the Debt limit has to be raised, otherwise, the world would collapse. If we tighten our belts drastically and pay the interest on the debt as it comes due, (which is what the average Joe has to do in bad times and good), there may be no need for the debt limit to be raised.

We ground our kids when they get out of control. It is time we put our Government, Wall Street gamblers bankers and their enablers in the corner like a 4 yr old. Grounding is not enough.

Oh, this shouldn't be your last column!  I think you would be a great replacement for the irreplaceable Frank Rich.  I miss his columns but yours have been excellent and I'd like to be able to continuing reading what you have to say.  Thank you.

mr. cohan, you chastize the powerless for being powerless.
Why not chastize those who know what happened and could have done something (Mr. Obama and Mr. Holder), and for those whose unseemly profits still lard their nests (Fuld, Blankfein, et al), while the rest of the country continues to get skimmed.
Soon we will have to take back the private property of the rich, that actually belongs to the people, who have paid and are paying still, for their excesses..Soon the state will begin to wage war on the people, and we will be shot at by policemen, stopped by militia, as we try to right these wrongs..
So much of the world is already in this state..
It seems so obvious that that is our future...We are just a couple of hundred years behind Egypt, behind Libya - not in front of it, behind it - isn't it obvious..
The future is a desert, with the single oasis ringed by a crown of thorns.
Maybe we should all migrate to Canada.
